newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian rate cut may not squeeze bank margins.
newsitem.headline: Australian rate cut may not squeeze bank margins.

text.p: Australian banks will not necessarily see their margins eroded further after Friday's official interest rate cut although it was too soon to identify a bottom line impact, analysts said.
"I'm not sure it will have a major impact," said analyst Michael Pulman of ABN Amro Hoare Govett.
"It will depend on just where the variable rates of the banks settle. If they only cut them by 0.35 percent, I would think that would fairly adequately offset the pressure."
The Reserve Bank of Australia cut the official cash rate to 5.5 percent from 6.0 percent.
Rates were last cut in December 1996 when the official cash rate was brought down to 6.0 percent from 6.5 percent.
Since then competitive conditions in the home loan market have meant a reduction of about 0.7 percentage points without a corresponding cut in official rates.
To protect their home loan business from mushrooming mortgage originators, banks have been forced to cut their rates, with consequent pressure on margins.

This pressure manifested itself in a sharp selloff of bank shares last week after National Australia Bank Ltd and Westpac Banking Corp posted stronger first half profits, but confirmed domestic margins were narrowing.

How much of the cut was absorbed by the banks was obviously a key issue in any discussion on margins, with analysts noting that less than the full amount had been passed on by three of the big four banks that had released a response so far.

"Having already cut housing rates by 70 basis points earlier in the year without a corresponding cut in the cash rate, you could say thay have passed on most of this rate cut already," said Steven Kench of Prudential-Bache Securities (Australia) Ltd.
"The difference is just the competitive nature of the housing market."
Other analysts echoed similar sentiments, saying the tighter conditions meant banks were likely to be judicious in pricing.
"Given they have only brought it down 35 points and not the full 50, they are obviously not willing to go any further than they have to," said an analyst at a Melbourne stockbroker.
Kench noted the same pricing pressures, but said it was too soon to detail a definitive effect although he conceded it could hurt banks further down the line.
"It depends on the ability of the banks to manage the interest rate cut within their balance sheets," he said.
"But it has the potential to add some more pressure."
By Friday's close, NAB shares were 34 cents higher at A$18.79 and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd shares were 13.5 cents higher at A$8.315.
Commonwealth Bank were up four cents at A$14.13 while Westpac, yet to release its response to the rate cut, was five cents lower at A$7.19.
